text: Hi, I’m Francis,
the host of this show "Cooking with Dog."
First, let’s make the dough.
Beat the egg in a bowl.
Add the sugar.
And thoroughly mix together.
Then, add the vegetable oil.
And Mix again.
Next, combine the cake flour and the baking powder.
Mix the powder in a bowl.
Then, sieve the powder into the bowl of the egg mixture.
We recommend using cake flour in this recipe
to help create a soft texture
but you can also use all purpose flour instead.
Now, using a paddle,
combine the ingredients with a slashing motion.
Avoid over-mixing otherwise
the soft texture will be lost when deep-fried.
Then, fold the dough until all the flour is mixed in.
Now, the dough is ready.
And now, let’s deep-fry the sata andagi.
Heat the oil to 150°C (302°F),
which is a relatively low temperature for deep-frying.
Wet your hands with vegetable oil
and spoon the dough onto your hand.
Shape it into a ball about the size of a ping pong ball.
Gently place the dough pieces into a pot
and slowly deep-fry them at a low temperature.
You’ll have about 10 dough pieces in total
but today, we will only cook 5 of them.
The dough will turn by itself so disturb it as little as possible
otherwise it’ll be less likely to have its signature cracks.
The expression ‘sata andagi smiles’ refers to the cracks
on its surface because the cracks look like the shape of smile.
Sata means ‘sugar’, anda means ‘oil’ and agi means ‘deep-fry’
in the Okinawan dialect, which is why the snack is called Sata Andagi.
Now, they are ready.
Remove the donuts
and place them onto a tray covered with a paper towel.
If your andagi doesn’t smile,
it is probably caused by the following reasons.
The oil temperature is too high, the dough is too runny
or it is moved too much while cooking.
Sata Andagi is also known as Sato Tempura, meaning ‘sugar tempura’
since the dough has a relatively large amount of sugar.
Good luck in the kitchen!
